title: Kenya: Laymen Teach Pupils As Teachers Strike
text:
By Alice Waithera 
Social workers, university students and unemployed tutors are teaching primary schools after Murang'a teachers went on strike. 
The volunteer teaching programme started at Karung'e Primary School in Mathioya and is expected to expand while the strike continues. 
The teachers' boycott entered its second week on Monday. 
The programme is sponsored by Ahadi Kenya Trust. 
Chief executive Stanley Kamau, who visited the school on Monday, said the strike will hurt KCPE and KCSE candidates. 
He said the strike places children in public schools at a disadvantage, compared to their counterparts in private schools. 
Kamau said Ahadi Kenya's plan will ensure all primary schools in the county have volunteer teachers. 
He said the volunteer teaching will cushion students from effects of the salary impasse between teachers and the government. 
Kamau called upon Kenyans to start similar programmes in other counties. 
"Most Kenyans watch the teachers' strikes on television and other media outlets, yet choose not to do anything," he said. 
The CEO urged teachers and the government to engage in dialogue, instead of threats, to end the feud. 
Kamau was accompanied by MCA Duncan Njuguna, who said only Karung'e is operational out of the 19 public primary schools in his ward. 
"The constant strikes defeat the essence of free primary education," Kamau said. Kenya
